comments.commentBody:
@Clairette Rose,

We can agree to disagree. I think the focus has to be on the user far more than the implement. We want the same thing, we just have different ways of going about it.
Should knives be registered, too?

I believe the killer is responsible for his crimes.

I also hold the police responsible for not doing their job, They could have prevented this incident from occurring.

The reason it's easy for an obviously seriously mentally ill person to get a gun is not because of a lack of gun control laws. There are already laws on the books preventing someone who is adjudicated mentally ill from owning a gun. The problem is getting the person so adjudicated.

@Paul,

I thought you would exempt antiques from your ban on gun promotion.

SEM,

Yes, I was asking if the objections to previous proposed mental illness reporting laws by gun control groups had merit. You said you don't think they did, but can't explain what the objections were, or why you objected to them. What that tells me is that your blaming the NRA for obstructing previous laws is not based on substance, but simply your own preconceptions.

I am sure I will not convince you out of your own prejudices, but you have convinced me that your own opinions about the issue ar without merit.

Wow, Mr. Trantor: You have effectively summed up what is wrong with the US today in a few short paragraphs; Privatization and 'Profits over people' at every turn, aided and abetted by Congress, the SCOTUS, the breaking of the Unions. I hadn't connected the dots about privatization across industries until your post, despite rigorous studies on the topic. (Google NE PA "Cash for Kids" to see first hand the horrors of prison privatization)
Everything seems slanted to enslave the working classes with student debt, high taxes, loss of safety nets, lack of upward mobility. The next "Occupy" should be at Colleges and Universities, whose prices, building and infrastructure projects chugged along happily through the Great Recession on the backs of the tuition-paying students and tax payers.
Thanks for your post!

Joseph.....If the rich have the lowest tax rates in generations, and yet still pay the majority of our taxes--what does that say? That simply attests to the huge, mammoth, gargantuan share of our wealth they've been able to amass. Not that our system is unfair to the poor, poor rich.

That's a good definition of confiscation --from the 99 up to the 1 percent. And then the victimizers of the majority victims, (that's us) cry that big bad govt (that's us ) wants to victimize them, by raising their taxes to that of previous generations, when we had different standards of fairness. And a upward mobility and security for the middle/working class.

And thanks to your reminder from Pennsylvania of the criminal Kids for Cash scheme. The 2 judges who committed those crimes are now in prison--I hope it's not pleasant. They schemed to imprison ordinary teenagers for small infractions, ruining young lives and their families, to get kick backs from private profit prisons---i think amounting to millions.

This is what happens when an entire political system is increasingly geared to using all public services and functions for private profit--which completely contradicts a century or 2 of progress toward individual rights of the average person. The criminals in public office come out of the woodwork like vermin to exploit and grab.

When you hear politicians denigrating govt itself, they are laying down the excuses for official crimes of this sort.

America has become a welfare state. However, the welfare has nothing to do with the 99%. Welfare today is specifically for the rich. That welfare is designed to transfer as much wealth as possible from the 99% to the 1% aided and abetted by Congress.
For the past 40 years we've privatized many industries. By privatizing the prison system, we have the largest prison population in the world Per capita.
We privatized student loans resulting in the largest student loan debt in the world.
We privatize healthcare ending up with the highest healthcare costs in the world...without better outcomes.
Without turning off or quieting the conservative propaganda machine where most low information voters get their information, welfare for the rich will continue unabated.
Typo correction on the number of 15 round mags.  I have SIX, not FIVE.

Discussant: I have noticed comments you make when ever psychotherapy is discussed here at NYTimes. I agree that there are some terrible therapists (and probably terrible practitioners in every field).

Just as likely, I could mention many examples of good treatment; many patients who have been well-served by the profession and are satisfied with the results.

Unfortunately, most of your posts focus on the negative, and refer to many of the same websites over and over - which in them self are biased). This seems like a campaign to alert the public to the fact that there are bad therapists, although I think most people know this already. But there are also good ones who are not on power trips, exploiting people through fostering weakness and dependency, and many other claims that you make. Since you tout strong scientific methodology, perhaps you could get good stats on how many patients are helped, how many are harmed, and how many are neutral, conducted with broad samples. Until I read satisfactory data on this, I will be concerned about your biases as well. Please help us all understand the broad picture we are trying to explore, not just the negative. Thanks!
So now 22-year-olds driving BMWs (how many can claim that?) become deprived-feeling mass shooters.  What's next...Goldman Sachs traders and hedge-fund managers on a gun rampage?
these incidents are not rare unfortunately. They're becoming all too routine.

It seems like everyone is in denial-the sheriffs, the therapists, the gun store owners, and the parents. They are all to blame, but the parents are the ones who stand out. Where were they when their son was buying guns? Did they get him a Beamer to try and placate him. Why did the father hire a lawyer to put the spin out that it is society's fault? It seems like deflection from the due diligence that he should have done. They need to be held accountable.

As for their son purchasing guns, the law needs to be changed so that anyone under 25 gets not only gets a background check, but the parents should be contacted regarding a history of anyantisocial behavior. If they deny it and the truth comes out, then they are culpable. The sheriffs need to do a more thorough investigation because at the time they interviewed him, he had posted those videos online. I could be wrong about the timeline. It seems that this sheriff is trying to cover his butt. And finally, therapists need to report a kid like him, even if he has not committed a crime. If they can tell he's an accident waiting to happen then who can.
As we saw he was a walking time bomb. I have no sympathy for him, but I pray for the parents who lost their kids. They didn't deserve it.

I hate to see people who are mentally ill stigmatized.  Most of them aren't a threat to anyone but themselves.  Most people do become very angry from time to time, and the more guns there are throughout society, the more people will die.  Even without mental illness per se, there were always plenty of people with an anger management problem.  In the days before guns were so widely distributed, most of the victims of those with anger management problems ended up with nothing worse than a bloody nose.

Therapists can't help people like this and people need to wake up and realize it.
We can't cure all cancers, either.
It's time to start looking for other solutions.
No amount of therapy or meds would have worked with this guy or others like him.

ERROL, I suggest that changing the 2nd Ammendment to prevent it from facilitating the needless deaths of tens of thousands of Americans a year is not by any definition "flippant."  As currently interpreted by our utterly anti restrictive Supreme Court the 2nd Ammendment threatens rather than promotes the general Welfare of the nation and its citizens ability to pursue their happiness. It needs to be ammended or abolished. There is no well trained militia to support for the defense of the local landwners from enraged Indians or British from Canada.
Maybe it's time to adopt Chris Rock's policy.  Have as many guns as you want.  Make ammunition, via taxes, as expensive as possible.
The problem is a lack of discipline. This will turn out to be another case affluenza.
Alas, if the carnage of 20 kids in Newtown did not signal introspection, I hardly think this one will.

You have a good point, in theory. But you're ignoring the "externality problem" described in the article. No individual's action can mitigate climate change through actions like your acorn planting example. Climate change is global, a much large problem. Everyone has a strong personal incentive to take a free ride by letting other people take action. Individual action is not a realistic way to address the problem because humans aren't saints.
If human aren't saints, then how can governments, who are actually just humans, act in a saintly manner?

Humans aren't saints, but over time I think we've become more aware and more sensitive. And above all, humans can be conditioned to change their behaviour when absolutely necessary. It looks like most of us still don't feel the reality of the coming crunch.

Your best insurance against climate change is to change your own lifestyle. If you represent a company, change the way the company operates.

Treat the earth with respect. Nature is an open book. Nature is the only real university. Learn to read what Nature is telling us.

The land is drying out. Why? What have we done and what are we doing that facilitates desertification? Do our agricultural practices contribute? (Yes they do.) Would we be better off to restore diverse forests because forests are buffers against climate volatility? Trees harvest and meter out the use of water to the land. In Provence, France one man changed the climate by planting acorns for over 20 years, each and every day.

We are legion. We are 7 billion. Act. Make the difference.

Why not ask what we are doing, and not just ask incompetent governments to save us? Why not change how we live?

Might not doing so be the most effective and least expensive insurance for each and all of us?

Why would they waste their time on comic books? I would wager, that President Obama read that many " adult reading " books in his first year in Office! The Bush boys have one thing in common, it is their underlying support for a meaningless Republican agenda: political power! They will get it any way they can. Senior donned a voodoo doctor's suit. W. donned the court jester outfit to Cheney's regal Vice-Presidency! J. had the Supreme Court interject its meddling into state's business. No, the Bushes, like most Republicans, can't bring nothing new to the table, except a new veneer on an old, rotting agenda, the Republican agenda!

I would hope they've been too busy to indulge in so much book reading while in office. Also, their party is not so conflicted as Mr. Bush's, not plagued by the inconsistencies of Republicanism. Thus they have less need for political self-help.

Obama and Clinton are far too busy for such luxuries. They have jobs to do, unlike Master Jeb who is free to contemplate just how he can accommodate the one or two percenters by rigging elections and cutting funds for the needy, whilst providing subsidies to the petroleum lords and those oh so needy conglomerate farmers who reap their benefits by not growing crops that might be used to feed those who are starving.

Mock Jeb Bush all you want -- and I'm as fatigued with the Bush Family as much as the next guy -- but I'd bet neither Barack Obama nor Hillary Clinton have read 25 books in the last five years. Combined.

This puff piece from the NY Times is nauseatingly one sided and simple minded.

Along side of Jeb’s reading list, I would love to see a bit more investigative reporting or references to earlier reporting of:

1. The purge of eligible voters, mostly African American, undertaken by Jeb’s Secretary of State, Katherine Harris, prior to the 2000 presidential election. It is widely thought that the purge tilted the election in favor of Jeb's brother who had an advantage of only 537 votes when the conservative SCOTUS, made up by Republican presidential appointees, stopped the recount mandated by the Florida Supreme Court which had rightfully interpreted its own State laws with respect to the recount. Included in the ugly story should be the legality of Harris halting the recount and certifying brother Bush the winner, setting the stage for the appeals;

2. Jeb’s signing into law “Terri’s Law”, interfering with the constitutional right of a person in a persistent vegetative state to have life support withdrawn when that person’s advanced directives can be proven;

3. Jeb’s ties to “ALEC” through his educational foundations that support private for profit educational institutions; and

4. Jeb’s rationale for vetoing Florida's high speed rail legislation that his constituents supported and the Florida legislature formulated.

I could go on but I want to get this in before the comments close!
As intellectually curious as he may be, he still questions whether climate change is caused by humans.
Amen, Jeb Bush running for president is abusive, narcissistic arrogance. His RINO policies aside, its the worst judgement, an insult to the party, and purely ego driven madness.

"Jeb Bush Gives Party Something to Think About"

I've done all the "thinking" about the Bush family that I can stand in one life.
Here's your chance -- let's hear them!
Yes, it applies to Hillary as well.
